outcomeList.title: Develop a message flow which receieves messages from a MQ queue.
Learn how to route the message to a local or remote queue using JavaCompute.
Understand how to connect MQInput and MQOutput nodes to specific queues and queue managers.

sections.section: This tutorial demonstrates how to create a connection to pass messages between IBM Integration Bus and WebSphere MQ. You will also see how to use a simple JavaCompute node to route the message.
Websphere MQ is a program to program service used for sending messages across different platforms. Generally you will use an Input queue and an Output queue to send and receive messages.
The JavaCompute node will search through an XML message tree to assess the value of the <ConnType> property and route the message to the specified location.

sections.section: In this section you will be configuring the MQInput and MQOutput nodes to connect to the queues in Websphere MQ.

The following assumes that you have installed and are running Websphere MQ. If not then use the link below for assistance. Run the batch file (MQCommandPrompts.bat) and this will set up WebSphere MQ to work for this tutorial.
Once you have completed these steps, return to IIB and open the MQNodePropertiesMain message flow.

details.details: To configure the MQRemoteInput node to your Input queue click on it and go to the properties tab. Under the Basic tab enter the name of the queue you created 'Remote_Input'. Go to the MQ Connection tab and from the drop down menu select 'MQ Client Connection Properties'. In Destination queue manager name enter 'Tutorial_QM_Remote' as this is where the Remote_Input queue is found. Under Host name enter your IP address, the listener port number is 1234 and the channel name is 'IIB.CLNT.CONN' (These were all set up from the batch file). Finally, on the Input Message Parsing tab set the message domain to 'XMLNSC' - this tells the node that you will be sending it an XML message.
For the MQRemoteOutput node on the Basic tab set the queue name to Remote_Output and set the MQ Connection settings to the same as the input node.

For the MQFailureOutput and MQLocalOutput nodes on the basic tab enter the queues Failure_Output and Local_Output repectively and on the MQ Connection tab set the connection to a Local Queue Manager and enter the name Tutorial_QM_Local.

sections.section: In this final section you will send a simple XML message through the flow you have developed.

details.details: Click the Flow Exerciser icon to start recording the message path through the flow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.
Choose either the LocalConnection or RemoteConnction message and click Send. Your request message is sent to the MQRemoteInput node.

sections.section: After the message has been processed, the message path is automatically highlighted on the message flow.

Click on any connection to see the data that passed through that connection. You can see that the request (input) message data has a field named ConnType. The response (output) message has been routed according to this.
To stop recording the message path through the flow, click the Return flow to edit mode icon .
Please note: You will have to stop and delete the queue managers in MQ manually. To do this right-click on the QM and select disconnect, once this process has finished you can delete it.
